intro: Aphanamixis davaoensis, commonly known as the Davao mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant belonging to the Loranthaceae family. It grows on the branches of host trees, primarily in the lowland forests of the Philippines. The plant has small, leathery leaves and produces white or yellowish flowers that are often clustered together. Its berries are typically red or orange, containing seeds that are dispersed by birds. Due to its limited distribution and ecological significance, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
